You'll laugh your ass off when he's high on pot and he'll scare the shit out of you when he is possessed.  His range in this film is expansive and proves that he was a terrific underrated actor who was just coming into his own before he got very ill in 2002 and never recovered, passing away in 2014. I still fondly remember him as the dog psychiatrist in the Begging Strip TV Commercials. This was co-screenwriter Lee Wasserman's only theatrical screenplay and he was also an Associate Producer here. The DVD & Blu-Ray put out by Code Red are nearly flawless and the fanciful sophisticated color scheme of the film is represented beautifully on your TV screen. I just wonder why the Blu-Ray doesn't contain the theatrical trailer and the DVD does. Still, both versions do let you view the cut scenes but, really now, how much trouble would they have been to reinsert them into the film? As far as I could tell, the cut scenes were already musically scored, so it couldn't have been that much trouble except that the cut scenes are in fullscreen and the film is in anamorphic widescreen. I would have accepted the cut scenes being in fullscreen. But, that's just a small complaint in an otherwise superb film. If you don't have this film in your library, you should. Also starring Susan Peretz (a superb character actress who is the apartment complex's owner), Brian Christian (also an Executive Producer; he plays the bus driver), the diminutive Tony Cox as an apartment resident, Muriel Minot, Harry Caesar, Pearl Adell, and Ed Berke. A Code Red DVD & Blu-Ray Release. Rated R. UPDATE: Now available on deluxe three-disc Blu-Ray from Severin Films, in two different cuts; the theatrical cut and the extended Dutch video version. It also includes a CD of Alan Howarth's music soundtrack as well as the copious extras which Severin is known for.

RUNAWAY NIGHTMARE (1982) - I doubt that you'll find a stranger film like this one in a long while. Two worm and snail farmers (Director Michael Cartel and Al Valletta) witness a live burial in the Death Valley, California desert.  They dig up the body and find a breathing nude girl in the coffin. They take her back to their farm and they themselves are kidnapped by a group of all-female cult members. After numerous lame jokes and a gunfight gone terribly wrong, the two men are voted into the group, entitling them to share in all their communal property. It seems the girls were dealing with the Mafia and were cheated out of a load of platinum (!?). The girls make the men do menial chores like chopping wood into splinters and moving boxes from one place to the next for no apparent reason. You'll be shaking your head in disbelief as you witness one inane scene after another, strung together for no other purpose than to make the film a decent running time. One of the guys gets a hot foot (!) while another scene shows a girl destroying a TV with an axe after being rebuffed for sex by one of the guys. The men have sex with the girls except for one who is a lesbian ("I hate MEN!"). The men help the girls get back their platinum from the Mafia.  I haven't even scratched the surface of this weird film. There are bar fights, gun fights, girl fights, a warehouse explosion, strip chess, pinball playing and vampirism! Absolutely no one in this film can act a lick. One wonders where director Michael Cartel's (who also acted in the 1974 sexploitationer PETS) head was at when he made this atrocity (Thank God, his only one). Was it up his ass or was he just high on peyote? In either case, you will be glued to the screen just to view and believe the awfulness of it. You won't be able to take your eyes off of it because of the sheer badness in every aspect of filmmaking it shows. It's the REEFER MADNESS of the 80's. Also starring Cindy Dolan, Jody Lee Olhava, Cheryl Gamson, Georgia Durante and Sijtske Vandenberg. An All Seasons Entertainment Home Video Release. Not Rated because it contains a lot of nudity (which seems inserted after the movie was finished because it looks like it was shot on videotape) but, oddly, contains very little blood or gore. This is one weird film that will have your head shaking in disbelief so much, that you're likely to get whiplash! Now available on DVD & Blu-Ray from Vinegar Syndrome with the nude video inserts removed and included as extras (seems like the All Seasons Entertainment VHS was unauthorized).

THE SEVENTH CURSE (1986) - This Raymond Chow Production for his Golden Harvest Films is a great mixture of action, adventure and horror elements, all done in the usual wild Hong Kong style, thanks to director Nam Nai Choi (a.k.a. "Simon Nam"; HER VENGEANCE - 1988; RIKI-OH: THE STORY OF RICKY - 1991), producer Wong Jing (HARD BOILED 2: THE LAST BLOOD - 1991; who plays a girl-happy wannabe playboy at a poolside party) and screenwriter I Kuang (HUMAN LANTERNS - 1982). The film opens at a cocktail party, where Mr. Yi (screenwriter I Kuang, also the film's narrator) tells a group of people about the latest adventure of Dr. Yuan Cheng-ha (Chin Siu-Hou; FIST OF LEGEND - 1994), a famous explorer and archaeologist (Dr. Yuan Cheng-ha is actually at the cocktail party, but he is too modest to tell the story. Or maybe he might like the way Mr. Yi embellishes it.). The story opens with a group of terrorists taking over a hospital and asking for a doctor to attend to one of their hostages, who has had a heart attack. Enter Dr. Yuan, who agrees to help the hostage with female police Inspector Chiang (Kara Hui), who is pretending to be his nurse (They plan on planting a flash grenade in the hospital to confuse the terrorists long enough for the police to rush in and save the hostages). Idiotic news reporter Tsai Hung (Maggie Cheung; THE HEROIC TRIO - 1993) knocks-out Inspector Chiang (with a brick to the back of her head!) and takes her place, following Dr. Yuan into the hospital to get the story of a lifetime (other reporters on the scene mockingly call her "Wonder Woman"). Once in the hospital, Dr. Yuan begins administering to the heart attack victim, but Tsai Hung draws unwanted attention to herself when she shows she doesn't even know the basics of first aid. Dr. Yuan bravely saves the day by setting off the flash grenade (just after one SWAT team member is graphically shot in the head) and kicking the shit out of the head terrorist, while the cops kill all the other terrorists. Amazingly, Dr. Yuan lets Tsai Hung off the hook and congratulates the now-conscious Inspector Chiang on a job well done in front of her boss, Captain Ho (all Inspector Chiang can do is scratch her head in befuddlement). Dr, Yuan is constantly hounded by Tsai Hung, who wants to do a story on his life, but Dr. Yuan doesn't care for her (besides, he has a beautiful white girlfriend, played by Joyce Godenzi, who is now Samo Hung's wife). At his palatial home, Dr. Yuan is attacked by Heh Lung (Dick Wei; WITCH FROM NEPAL - 1985) and a glass-shattering fight ensues. When the fight is over, Heh Lung informs Dr. Yuan that a blood spell was performed on him nearly a year ago and he needs to travel to Thailand to have it removed before he dies. Dr. Yuan doesn't believe it, but he changes his tune rather quickly when all the veins in his leg start swelling while he is making love to his girlfriend and one of them bursts, spraying blood all over her. A flashback reveals how a blood spell was put on Dr. Yuan when he visited Northern Thailand a year earlier. He and a group of explorers, including the Professor (Ken Boyle; OPERATION CONDOR 2: THE ARMOUR OF THE GODS - 1987), witnessed a sacrificial ceremony performed by the Worm Tribe and Dr. Yuan saves a beautiful young girl, Betsy (Tsui Sau-Lai), the fiancée of Heh Lung, from being sacrificed by evil sorcerer Aquala (Elvis Tsui, who keeps a bloodthirsty baby-like creature called a "Little Ghost" on his back and sends it out to eat his enemies from the inside-out!). After saving Betsy from the "Old Ancestor" (a skeletal creature that likes to chew on human flesh and then transforms into a winged ALIEN [1979]-like monster), Dr. Yuan and the Professor are captured (the rest of their party is butchered by the Worm Tribe) and Aquala pours goop over the Professor's head, forcing his body to erupt in a shower of maggots (Dr. Yuan pukes at the sight). Aquala then performs the blood spell on Dr. Yuan, but before he can complete it, Dr. Yuan uses a magnifying glass to burn off the ropes that bind him and escapes, while veins and arteries in his body explode. A naked Betsy slices off a piece of her breast (!) and makes Dr. Yuan eat it, which temporarily cures him of his affliction, but for only a year (Which beggars the question: Why did Dr. Yuan dismiss Heh Lung's warning a year later?). Now, with the help of best friend Mr. Wei (Chow Yun Fat) and Tsai Hung (who turns out to be Mr. Wei's cousin!), Dr. Yuan returns to Thailand to remove the blood spell before his heart bursts. This is going to be one wild, violent and bloody ride!  If you ever wondered what an Indiana Jones film would look like with ultra-bloody violence and plenty of gore (it makes the heart-ripping scene in INDIANA JONES AND THE TEMPLE OF DOOM [1984] look like a Disney film), then look no further. Director Nam Nai Choi fills THE SEVENTH CURSE with so much bloody action set pieces, including martial arts fights, gun battles, encounters with weird creatures and Dr. Yuan popping blood vessels at the most inopportune times, I can't imagine that any fan of Weird Asia can afford to pass this up. There are also some truly amazing stunt sequences on view (it is hard to conceive that some stuntmen weren't seriously injured here, especially when Dr. Yuan drives his Range Rover into the middle of the Worm Tribe's village, knocking over tribe members like bowling pins), children being sacrificed, booby traps, weird tribal rituals and monster battles (Believe me, you haven't truly seen it all until you witness the Little Ghost fight the fully-transformed Old Ancestor. It puts ALIENS VS. PREDATOR: REQUIEM [2007] to shame) to please even the most jaded action/adventure/horror fan. Be aware that Chow Yun Fat has a secondary role here and doesn't do much more than act scholarly. Chin Siu-Hou and Dick Wei are the action stars here and they perform admirably, along with scores of stunt personnel. Bloody good show, I say. Also known as DR. YUEN AND WISELY, but the English subtitles betray this, as Yuen is spelled "Yuan" and Chow Yun Fat's character is changed from Wisely to "Wesley" or Mr. Wei. Also starring Chor Yuen, Sibelle Hu and Yasuaki Kurata. Available on DVD & VCD from Fortune Star as part of their "Legendary Collection" (the English subtitles are hard-coded and sometimes hard to read since most of the films in the Legendary Collection are not remastered). Not Rated.

SCORPION THUNDERBOLT (1985) - What is the fascination with snakes in Oriental cinema? Fourteen women have been brutally murdered by a giant snake-like creature and the police are clueless. A vampire witch with long metallic fingernails performs a ritual while Richard (Richard Harrison) is screwing a female hitchhiker in a porno screening room. The hitchhiker pulls out a knife and tries to stab Richard, but he stops her and she dies while spewing yellow goo out of her mouth. A cackling madman breaks into policeman Jackie's (Bernard Tsui) apartment, handcuffs him, rapes his girlfriend and injects her with a drug. Jackie manages to free himself from the handcuffs and beats the crap out of the laughing madman while three young women watch the fracas from their apartment window. The snake creature then kills the three women in their apartment while a blind man plays the flute outside. Another madman has a woman in his apartment tied spread-eagle while he plays a game of nine ball with her vagina (he shoots pool balls with his cue right at her snatch!). Richard is nearly killed by a plumber he calls to fix his leaky pipes, but kills him with the exercise bar he was using to work out. Jackie and his girlfriend are then attacked in their moving car when it suddenly fills with snakes. They crash but manage to escape. Does this review seem severely fragmented? Believe me when I tell you that this is nothing compared to watching this film. It seems the vampire witch has something to do with newspaper reporter Helen (Juliet Chan) turning into a snake monster at the worst times imaginable. She attacks and kills a waiter and a couple taking a bath while transformed into the snake creature and her cheating boyfriend Jackie begins to worry about her. Meanwhile, Richard is being attacked by people under the power of the Queen of Scorpions, the vampire witch, who wants the ring Richard is wearing, as it is the only object that can destroy her. Richard goes to a prophet, who gives him a golden sword and a mystical mirror to defeat the Queen. Helen confesses to Jackie by saying, "I am not a human being. I am a snake demon!" and then tells him a story (told in flashbacks) that is right out of a twisted Mother Goose tale. To make a long story short, everytime the Queen of Scorpions bangs on her tom-toms and the blind guy (who is a security guard!) plays his flute, Helen turns into the snake creature. In a scene that must be seen to be believed, Helen transforms into the snake creature in front of a bunch of policemen, grabs Jackie's real girlfriend and flies through the air. Jackie saves his girlfriend by slicing his chest open with a knife and letting the snake creature suck on the wound! In the finale, Helen is shot and killed while Richard must fight numerous possessed people before he can square off with the Queen of Scorpions using his ring, mystical mirror and golden sword.  Yes, this is another one of director Godfrey Ho's cut-and-paste jobs for producers Joseph Lai and Betty Chan (see reviews of COBRA AGAINST NINJA -1987 and NINJA THE PROTECTOR - 1986) for their IFD Films and Arts Ltd. production company, but this one is different. Instead of the usual martial arts chicanery, SCORPION THUNDERBOLT is an honest-to-goodness horror film and, although the newly shot footage of Richard Harrison has him fighting numerous opponents, not once does he or anyone else don a ninja costume (the old footage is taken from a Korean film titled GRUDGE OF THE SLEEPWALKING WOMAN [1983]). Since there's not a lot of interaction between the old and new footage, it doesn't seem overtly obvious like some of Ho's martial arts "epics". Nevermind that the film doesn't make any sense, there's a lot of things to like about this, from the crazy snake monster (it's jaw-dropping), the bloody murders (including in the flashback, where a guy [actually the flute player] gets his eyes yanked out of their sockets by a couple of snakes), the crazy set-pieces (I dare you not to laugh at the loony pool player), frequent nudity (even Richard Harrison get to screw a young woman) and, of course, the insane dubbed dialogue (after transforming from snake demon back to human form, Helen says to Jackie, "Jackie, my arms are sore!"). I'm beginning to appreciate these Godfrey Ho pastiches, even if it's for all the wrong reasons. You should dig this one, too. Also starring Nancy Lim, Cynthia Ku, Maura Fong, Samson Kim and Cathy Evan. Available on DVD from those thieving bastards at Videoasia/Ventura Distribution as part of their TALES OF VOODOO series (Volume 5). It's a slightly letterboxed, but overly dark, VHS port. Also available on DVD from Ground Zero, as part of their "Brooklyn Zu" series. Not Rated.

SICK-O-PATHICS (1996) - Just a word of warning: If you watch this extremely short SOV anthology film (47 minutes), a fictitious TV show made up of three "comic" episodes, a wraparound episode, with fake commercials between each episode, and think you are going to enjoy it, you have another thing coming. The only positive aspect of this poor, amateurish "film" is that it contains a bunch of Italian genre personalities in cameo roles and most of them are no longer with us. As a matter of fact, some of them passed away after appearing in this piece of dreck, making it the last time we would see them on film. It's not a good way to be remembered.
     The wraparound episode, titled "Hellcome", deals with a dreadlocked white dude named "Max O'Keest" (co-director Massimo F. Lavagnini; and c'mon now, groan!) walking down the street pushing everyone who is walking the other way. He rips off the arm of a young boy, just to get him to drop his lollipop, handing the arm to the boy's mother (who beats Max with it!). He then sees homemade signs of a pointing hand reading "This Way" and follows them, ending up in the mansion of horror film director Dare Dane (Dardano Sacchetti, one of Italy's best genre screenwriters, giving us such films as SHOCK - 1977; CITY OF THE LIVING DEAD - 1980; A BLADE IN THE DARK - 1983; and many, many others). When Max tells Dare Dane he hasn't seen any of his films, he knocks out Max with his cane and when he wakes up, Max discovers he is tied to a chair, Dare Dane forcing to watch his films, which he has on VHS. What follows are three short comic horror films, complete with cheesy, low-rent gore effects. After each episode, we are "privy" to some of the worst fake TV commercials ever committed to celluloid (if videotape can be considered such a thing).
     The first film, titled "Hello Dolly", finds an unnamed man, credited as the "Rude Dude" (Gianni Tarquini), walking into a sex shop and asking the owner, Mr. Sinister (Italy's premiere special effects master Sergio Stivaletti, who directed THE WAX MASK [1997] after appearing in this piece of shit), if his package has arrived yet. It has, but Mr. Sinister makes him sign a weird contract before giving it to him (which he bleeds on, making Mr. Sinister very happy) and letting him walk out the door with it. When the Rude Dude gets home, we find out that the package is a female blow-up sex doll and when he reaches into the box to pull it out, he gets a slimy substance on his hands. Thinking that the sex doll is used, the Rude Dud is disgusted, so he gets drunk, lies down in bed, reads a porno magazine and falls asleep. The doll then inflates by itself and walks towards the Rude Dude, where it ejaculates a semen-like substance out of its twat and mouth all over the man. A long, penis-like creature then shoots out of the doll's vagina and bites the Rude Dude on his arm. He is then engulfed in a semen cocoon, as his body shrivels up. The next day, a woman (the single monikered Chantal) walks into the sex shop and Mr. Sinister hands her a package (and contract to sign). It's a male blow-up doll that looks exactly like the Rude Dude. So this is how sex dolls are made!?! The fake commercial that follows this episode shows Lucio Fulci (!) shilling a new drink called "Lokula". He not only looks embarrassed shilling it, he died a few months later!
     The next short film, titled "The Poor, The Flesh And The Bag" concerns a poor man (Loris Curci; producer/actor on ZONE OF THE DEAD - 2009) owing money to the big Drug Boss (late director Renato Polselli, who gave us such gonzo films as THE VAMPIRE AND THE BALLERINA - 1960; DELIRIUM - 1972; and MANIA - 1974). He gives the poor man two days to pay up or he's dead, so he looks for some way to make fast money. That opportunity comes when a woman (Mary Rinaldi; dialogue writer for FATAL FRAMES [1996] a terrible movie many of the people in this "film" also appeared in or worked on to some extant) leaves her briefcase in a store and walks away without it. The poor man grabs it and takes it back to his apartment, hoping to find something valuable inside it, but he can't manage to open it. It turns out that the briefcase is alive (extremely funny for the cheap way it is animated) and devours the poor man, then turns its attention to the poor man's girlfriend (Manuela Azzeroni), also devouring her. The briefcase returns to the home of its female owner, who turns out to be a witch/cannibal! She opens the briefcase, pulls out all the severed body parts inside it and puts them in her refrigerator. She then leaves the briefcase in another store and walks away without it. Next victim, please! The commercial that follows this episode shows cannibalistic butcher Luigi Cozzi (director of STARCRASH - 1978; CONTAMINATION - 1980 and DEMONS 6: DE PROFUNDIS [THE BLACK CAT] - 1989) shilling a meat product called "Salumi Stella" ("Star Cold Cuts") and looking completely ashamed doing it.
     The final short film in this completely wasted exercise in tedium, and the longest of the three, is titled "Aeropophagus", which is an unfunny take-off of Joe D'Amato's ANTHROPOPHAGUS (a.k.a. THE GRIM REAPER - 1980), that mimics some scenes verbatim, yet lacks any talent or comedic performances, except for one person in particular. The first scene, which matches exactly the first scene in D'Amato's flick, shows a German couple walking down the narrow streets of an unnamed Greek island, where they stop at a beach and the woman goes for a swim in the ocean while the man relaxes on the beach and listens to music on some rather large headphones. The woman sees a rubber raft drifting aimlessly in the ocean and swims to it. When she looks inside it, she dissolves in the water. We then see someone's POV as they walk up to the oblivious man and farts in his face. We watch as the flesh dissolves off the man's skull (more cheap comic gore effects). Even his cassette player dissolves! (This is the only really good scene, as it copies D'Amato's film verbatim, right down to the couple speaking German to each other!). Cut to the present, where Dr. Loonies (David Warbeck; THE BEYOND - 1981; FORMULA FOR A MURDER - 1985; in one of his final film performances) tells patient Ricky (Ian Pavloc) that he has a disease worse than cancer. It turns out Ricky likes to eat garbage out of trash cans and also loves to smell shit-stained underwear. Dr. Loonies reveals to Ricky that he is wearing red bikini underwear, as he tells a frightened Ricky that he needs to examine him. Dr. Loonies decides to shock Ricky by showing him the "elephant trick", where he reaches into the front of his red bikini briefs and pulls out his penis, which looks like an elephant's trunk! (Why does he do this? I don't know, but a game Warbeck pulls it off with comic aplomb). He then tells Ricky that he needs a vacation on a small Greek island. As Ricky is flying to the Greece airport, he throws up (there's a not-so-sly reference to the "Nightmare at 20,000 Feet" episode of THE TWILIGHT ZONE) and the passenger sitting next to him (Marco Antonio Andolfi, as "Eddy Endolf"; director/star of the really strange THE CROSS OF SEVEN JEWELS - 1987) nearly passes out from the smell, but Ricky puts his face into the barf bag and takes a giant whiff, a smile coming across his face. Once on the island, a blind gypsy (Stefania Stella; FATAL FRAMES - 1996) tells Ricky that his odor is making the residents flee the island. She tells him she experienced this once before many years ago, when a shipwreck survivor, who survived on rotten cans of beans from the sunken ship's hold, washed up on shore. He was known as "the Man with The Farts" and the gypsy tells Ricky that he's coming to get him. What does this all mean? You got me, but this is the only time you will see a comic take-off of ANTHROPOPHAGUS. It's not really that funny (unless you find smelling used condoms hilarious), but David Warbeck gives it his all, looking like he's having the time of his life, which is what makes this episode tolerable, but his appearance is regrettably short, as the film ends with The Man With The Farts passing gas on a pregnant woman (Lucio Fulci's daughter, Antonella Fulci) on the beach, forcing her to abort her baby, who comes flying out of her vagina. He tries to kill Ricky with his farts, but he enjoys the smell, so Fartman he eats his own innards! This episode is followed by a commercial for "Dr. Riker's Hair Lotion", where actor Rick Gianasi testifies that the hair treatment saved his career, displaying his shiny long hair to an approving Linnea Quigley, who screams (they would both appear in FATAL FRAMES the same year).
     When the third short film ends, we see Max O'Keest break free from his binds and tie Dare Dane to the chair, only this time, Dane is facing the opposite way, unable to watch his own films, which he dearly loves. The end credits then play, which includes a dedication to Lucio Fulci and the following weird statements:
"Fuck Morphing!"

"Don't make unauthorized dupes, unless you don't want Max O'Keest to visit you at home." And:

"Wait a minute...we forgot somebody! Marcello Bonini was the owner of the newspaper shop...and we would like to thank Virio for drawing Lokula!"
     This third-rate anthology, directed/produced/written by the team of Massimo F. Lavagnini (a bit actor in FATAL FRAMES and 2nd 2nd Assistant Director on WITCHCRAFT IX: BITTER FLESH - 1997) and Brigida Costa (a bit actress in TERROR FIRMER - 1999 and 3rd Assistant Director on DEMONIUM - 2001), could hardly be called entertaining, but it is a hoot to see all the genre personalities who agreed to appear in this trifle. It makes me wonder if both directors had incriminating photos of these personalities, forcing them to appear in this turd. It is plain to see none of them (besides Warbeck) look like they are enjoying themselves, but, as an historical artifact, it does hold some importance to film viewers interested in Italian genre films. This SOV atrocity is nearly impossible to find in physical form and there's a reason for that. It is so bad, no one wants to release it, because it would be a major money loser. It did manage to find its way on VHS in Dutch-speaking countries from label Manic Entertainment, but it is next to impossible to find. Consider that a good thing because the amount of money asked for a copy is beyond what any sane person would pay for it. I managed to catch a fairly bad fullscreen print of it streaming on YouTube from user "Horrormania", so if you must watch this, hurry up, because YouTube is going on a deletion spree, it may no longer be there if you wait too long. This print is followed by footage taken at an Italian horror convention, where people who worked on the film (and some who didn't) praise this film as a comic masterpiece! Give me what they're smoking! Also featuring deceased directors Joe D'Amato (BEYOND THE DARKNESS - 1979) and Sergio Bergozelli (IN THE FOLDS OF THE FLESH - 1970; BLOOD DELIRIUM - 1988) as neighbors of the poor man in the second episode (if you blink, you'll miss them) and a bunch of other people who never appeared in another film. Not Rated.

SONNY BOY (1989) - I still haven't figured out this movie. Either it's one of the greatest put-ons ever committed to film or a serious statement about child abuse. It begins 17 years ago when Weasel (Brad Dourif) steals a red Caddy (after shooting the occupants) and brings it to Slue (big Paul L. Smith), who runs a stolen property ring on the outskirts of a barren desert town (filmed in Deming, New Mexico). Slue runs the town with an iron fist, the sheriff (Steve Carlisle) and all the occupants bow to his every whim or die. What Weasel doesn't realize is that there is a baby boy in the backseat of the Caddy and when Slue finds it, he wants to kill it or sell it. This doesn't sit well with Slue's wife, Pearl (played by David Carradine in drag!), who wants to keep it and raise it as her (his?) own. Slue relents, because he wants to keep Pearl happy, but practices a particular brand of tough love to the baby, who everyone now calls "Sonny Boy". As the years pass, we watch as Slue whips Sonny, crucifies him on a pole and sets a fire around him (to toughen up his skin!), and finally cuts his tongue out. Cut to the present and Sonny Boy (Michael Boston aka "Michael Griffin") is a feral animal, chained to a pole, filthy with tattered clothes. Slue uses Sonny for some of his more violent robberies, setting Sonny free to kill and eat Slue's robbery victims (including a priest, who tries to stop Sonny from stealing a statue of Christ off a cross). Things begin to go terribly wrong when Charlie (Sydney Lassick), one of Slue's yes-men cronies, and Weasel use Sonny for one of their private robberies, unknown to Slue. Sonny bites off the tip of Weasel's thumb and escapes, making his way to the town and killing a woman who comes on to him. The townspeople revolt and chase Sonny back to Slue's home. The mob kill Slue and Pearl, setting fire to the compound. A kindly doctor (Conrad Janis) saves Sonny, brings him home and attaches a monkey tongue (!) to Sonny, where the first word out of Sonny's mouth is "No!". I haven't really begun to scratch the surface of what this film has to offer the viewer. The acting is uniformly excellent by a cast of veterans, the music moody (including a haunting song titled "Paint", written and performed by Carradine), the photography (by Roberto D'Ettorre Piazzoli) elegant, and everything else is above par. SONNY BOY is likely to be one of your favorite films once you see it. David Carradine is a wonder here. If you thought he was supreme in KILL BILL (2003 - 2004), wait till you see him in this. He plays his role as a woman straight without a trace of campiness. You really feel the compassion, even if it's twisted, he/she shows for Sonny and Slue. Pay attention to Carradine's transformation through the 17 years.  Paul L. Smith (PIECES - 1982), Brad Dourif (he's excellent in HBO's DEADWOOD [2004 - 2006]) and the late Sydney Lassick (THE UNSEEN - 1980) give grimy performances as people berift of souls, especially in the shot of Slue blowing away an officer with a howitzer for questioning his orders. I'll leave the rest up to you to take in. Director Robert Martin Carroll has made just one other film: the hard to come by BABY LUV (1999 - a.k.a. BABIES FOR SALE), a surreal tale of baby-selling and the unexpected consequences that come with it. Based on these two films, someone should give Mr. Carroll some financing to start making more films! We need someone like him to juice-up the business. SONNY BOY is required viewing for anyone with an interest in the unusual, the way-out and the wacky. Also starring Savina Gersak, Alexandra Powers, Steve Ingrassia and Stephen Lee Davis.  Produced by Ovidio G. Assonitis (BEYOND THE DOOR - 1974; TENTACLES - 1977 and many others, sometimes using the pseudonym "Oliver Hellman"), which would explain why some reviewers seem to think that Carroll is a pseudonym for some Italian director. It's simply not true. A Media Home Entertainment Release. Rated R. This film screams for an uncut DVD release, since the version I saw on VHS seems to cut out some of the more brutal bloodletting. NOTE: This film had a midnight showing at the Landmark Nuart Theater in Los Angeles on May 12, 2006 with Mr. Carroll as guest speaker. USELESS TRIVIA: The lyrics for Carradine's song "Paint" now adorns a marker at his Forest Lawn Hollywood Hills resting place. Above the phrase "The Barefoot Legend", it reads: "I'm looking for a place where dogs don't bite and children don't cry and everything always goes just right and brothers don't fight." RIP David Carradine.

SOUL VENGEANCE (1975) - Originally titled WELCOME HOME BROTHER CHARLES when released to theaters, this film opens with Charles (Marlo Monte) standing on the edge of a building, ready to jump while a police detective tries to convince Charles' wife Christina (Reatha Grey) to talk him out of it. The film then flashes back in time to detail why Charles is in this predicament. Charles is a small time dope dealer who is busted by brutal white cop Harry (Ben Bigelow), who hates black people because his wife cheated on him with a black dude. Harry viciously beats Charles in the back of his squad car and caps it off by nearly castrating him with a straight razor. Harry's partner, Jim (Stan Kamber), is the exact opposite of Harry, but goes along with the beating because Harry is considered a hero in the public's eye because he diffused a bomb at an airport. When Charles is brought to trial, he is railroaded into prison by Harry's false testimony and the legal manouevers of a crooked prosecuting attorney. After three years in prison, Charles is released and learns that everything on the outside is much different now. Drugs are rampant, his girlfriend has been turned into a stripper by his best friend and his younger brother has joined a street gang. Hoping to stay on the straight and narrow, Charles gets a new girlfriend (and later wife) in ex-prostitute Christina and tries repeatedly to get a job, but time and time again he is unsuccessful. After seeing how everyone from his past that have done him wrong are now doing so well and seem to be prospering off of his misfortune, Charles decides some payback is in order. Since his release from prison, Charles has gained some unusual supernatural powers: The ability to get women to do anything he says just by staring in their eyes and the truly amazing ability to make his penis grow enormously long (I'm talking yards, not inches!). Long enough to strangle his enemies, which includes racist cop Harry, the conniving prosecuting attorney and the judge who presided over his trial.  This all leads back to the scene on the roof, where Christina offers Charles a one last word of advice (and it is chilling).  This amazingly cheap exploitation film (some may call it blaxploitation, but I think it offers more than that) comes to us courtesy of one man wunderkind Jamaa Fanaka (the PENITENTIARY trilogy [1979 - 1987]; STREET WARS - 1992), who always turned out one-of-a-kind jaw-droppers. SOUL VENGEANCE (his first film) is no different. It plays like a real cheapjack (but sincere) "Bad Man Goes Straight" drama (where, surprisingly, not a single gunshot is fired), where we witness Charles go through a series of setbacks, although he always manages to maintain his composure thanks to the loving care of Christina. That is, until the final third of the film. From the moment Charles goes to the doctor to discuss is unusual "condition", the film takes a sudden U-turn into the surreal. His seduction of Harry's wife (Tiffany Peters) right up to the subsequent penis strangulation of the prosecuting attorney (where we finally see the full monstrous monty in action) are classic moments of "What The Fuck?" cinema. Christina's final word to Harry (which freeze frames at that exact moment) is also unexpected but also rings true-to-life. It did give me goosebumps. SOUL VENGEANCE (I still think WELCOME HOME BROTHER CHARLES is a better title) is must-viewing for anyone interested in something really strange. It contains Fanaka's patented jumpy editing, static camera work and extreme close-ups, but the subject matter is straight out of the twisted mind of a madman. A madman named Jamaa Fanaka (whose real name is Walter Gordon). That's the reason why I like his films. They always go in a direction you don't expect them to. Also Starring Jake Carter, Jackie Ziegler and Ed Sander. A Xenon Pictures Release. Rated R.

THE SPIDER LABYRINTH (1988) - American professor Alan Whitmore (Roland Wybenga; SINBAD OF THE SEVEN SEAS - 1989) is about to experience a living nightmare that would give H.P. Lovecraft goosebumps. A nightmare so horrendous, it will make Alan relive his worst memories (He is deathly afraid of spiders, since getting locked in a closet with a big one when he was a young boy), as well as influence what little future he has left as a human being. This is one of the best Italian horror films of the late-'80s, as the visuals will make you squirm, the situations will give you chills and the ending will leave your jaw on the floor. Yes, it is that good.
     Alan is the coordinator of a secret project called "Intextus", in which professors and scientists the world over are working on, but we are not privy to...yet. One day, Alan is called into the office of Chancellor Hubbard (Bill Bolender), the head of the institute financing Intextus. Hubbard tells Alan that he must go to Budapest to talk to Professor Roth, who has cut off communication with the institute. Alan has to try and talk to Roth since only he could understand what the Professor has to say. Alan agrees to go, not knowing that his life is about to take a deadly turn, full of puzzles and, yes, labyrinths, of both the emotional and physical kind, but why is a priest in Hubbard's office? (As Alan leaves his office, Hubbard turns to the priest and says, "Perhaps we should have told him everything.") Once in Budapest, Alan meets one of Professor Roth's assistants, Genevieve (Paola Rinaldi), who picks him up from the airport and drives him to the Professor's house. Strange shit begins to happen almost immediately as Alan walks to the Professor's back door, where a young boy on a swing stares at him intensely and then seemingly disappears, the swing still moving. Professor Roth's wife, Celia (Margareta Von Krauss), answers the door, telling Alan to be gentle with her husband, as he has just had a nervous breakdown. Alan then meets Professor Roth (Massimiliano Pavone), who is deeply paranoid and wants Alan to prove to him he is who he says he is. Alan hands a letter to the Professor that was given to him by Chancellor Hubbard, who left implicit orders to give it to the Professor.  Once he reads the letter, Professor Roth is satisfied and hands Alan an ancient tablet, telling Alan that it contains all he needs to know about Intextus, but to tell no one that he has it. A black ball then shatters a window in the room and lands at Alan's feet. When Alan looks out the broken window to see where the ball came from, he discovers that Professor Roth is no longer in the room, as the ball seemed to scare him away (whenever the black ball appears, someone will soon die). Celia then enters the room, telling Alan that he should no longer have contact with her husband because he is very ill. Alan, who is a no-nonsense type of guy, tells Celia that he will return later that night and make up his mind for himself whether this is all for nothing. When he leaves the House, Genevieve is waiting for him, walking Alan to his hotel and telling him that she lives across the street from the hotel (this is also important). Once in the hotel's lobby, Alan meets the hotel's mysterious owner, Mrs. Kuhn (Stephane Audran; FACELESS - 1987), and her always-present black cat. Why does everyone in the lobby stare at Alan so intensely?
     Alan then goes through a series of seemingly unrelated mysterious events. First, there is a nameless stranger (William Berger; MAYA - 1988), who seems to know exactly where Alan is going, warning him to leave town immediately if he wants to live. Then he sees Genevieve through his hotel room window stripping naked (surprising full-frontal nudity), knowing he is watching and trying to turn him on. We also glean a little bit of information on what Intextus is about. Intextus seems to deal with an ancient religious sect whose god seems to be some sort of giant spider, a sect that has been in existence since 3000 BC, with members across the globe, yet it is so secret, little to nothing has been written about it and anyone who dares talk about it dies a horrible death (Alan says this to Genevieve about the members of the sect when they are in a Turkish bathhouse: "Like an enormous cobweb, they are connected to each other."). When Alan goes to talk to Professor Roth that night, he discovers the police and some residents gathered around the house. The police commissioner (Lazlo Sipo) escorts Alan into the house, where he discovers Professor Roth dead, hanging by a rope in the middle of the room, spider webs covering the rope. The police commissioner asks Alan what he is doing here, Alan telling him that he told the Professor's wife that he would be here that night. "That can't be.", says Genevieve (who is also in the room), "He was never married." Alan then tells the inspector about the black ball, but when he goes to show him the window it came through, the window is no longer broken. Is someone trying to frame Alan or is something beyond his comprehension going on?
     It doesn't take a genius to realize that Budapest is full of members of this secret sect (they all have a scar on their arm in the shape of a spider and we soon see firsthand how they got those scars!). When hotel housekeeper Maria (Claudia Muzii) warns Alan to leave as soon as possible, she is killed by what can best be described as a spider woman (or a black widow, if you will, since she is dressed in a flowing black gown and has wild red hair) who stabs the housekeeper in the middle of her forehead with a large butcher knife after chasing her through a labyrinth of hanging white sheets. Alan takes a look at the tablet Professor Roth gave him, discovering two Polaroid photos of the tablet inside it, with the name "Polgar Moricz" written on the back of the photos. Genevieve tells Alan that Polgar is the name of an antiques dealer and Alan is desperate to talk to him, but it won't be easy, for the directions to his antique shop in another labyrinth that Alan must navigate (a well-filmed sequence). Alan gets to the antique shop too late, as the spider woman has killed Polgar. Alan's fear of spiders gets a good workout, especially in the WTF?!? finale, which can best be describes as a hallucinogenic trip to the darker side of bizarre religious rites. I guarantee this: Once you see it, you will never forget it. Just who is this "spider woman"? Could it be someone that Alan knows?
     Even though the only actors recognizable in this film may be William Berger and Stephane Audrane, everyone here does a remarkable job in making us believe that all this supernatural horror is actually happening. There are a few standout scenes that will make the hair on the back of your neck stand up. The first one is when Alan and Genevieve are having dinner in the hotel's dining room. Everyone in the room have their eyes on Alan and when he starts talking about the religious sect, they all silently get up and walk out, leaving Alan and Genevieve the only ones in an empty dining room. Another memorable scene happens when Alan hears housekeeper Maria scream when she is being killed in the middle of the night. It leads Alan to a windowless room, where Mrs. Kuhn is rocking an empty cradle, describing to Alan how her young son died. This is extremely creepy, an unforgettable exercise in pure terror. There is also a highly effective sequence where the nameless stranger takes Alan to his hideout, the catacombs beneath the city, where he explains to Alan that the people in this sect are not human, they are "creatures" who have walked this Earth for thousands of years and they will kill anyone who threatens to expose them. He also tells Alan that they haven't killed him yet because they want to make him a member of their sect, He says to Alan that death is preferable than to go through one of the sect's rituals to turn human beings into creatures. The spider woman then kills the stranger in a very unusual way, while Alan tries to escape the catacombs, discovering the remains of past human victims of the sect in the labyrinth-like passageways of the catacombs. It is a sequence full of weird visuals (What is a Volkswagen Beetle doing in the catacombs?) and terrifying discoveries. But the standout sequence is the finale, which is part gore, part stop-motion photography (!) and totally unnerving, thanks to maestro Sergio Stivaletti's (DEMONS - 1985; CEMETERY MAN - 1994) remarkable visual effects. You will see some outrageous creations, such as a monster baby with spider mandibles on the top of its head morphing into a giant spider (you have to see it to believe it) and then showing us how those spider scars are created (it made me flinch and that isn't easy). I have to thank my friend Steven for turning me on to this film, because I always thought that Italian horror films went straight down the crapper in the late-'80s. Thanks for proving me wrong. This was director Gianfranco Giagni's only genre film of note. I would have liked to see him direct more films like this, as the majority of his other directorial output seems to be TV and film documentaries. He shows a sure hand here, moving the film at a brisk pace and not letting the viewer have a chance to realize how improbable the story actually is. The screenplay was written by Riccardo Aragno, Tonino Cervi (director/writer of QUEENS OF EVIL - 1970; he was also this film's Producer), Cesare Frugoni (SCREAMERS - 1980) and Gianfranco Manfredi, much in the way of a great mystery, only revealing something of importance to move the plot forward, leaving the viewer begging for more. When everything is finally revealed, you'll wish you never saw it, mainly because it is so disturbing. There are no happy endings here.
     Shot as IL NIDO DEL RAGNO ("The Spider's Nest"), this film never received a theatrical or home video release in the U.S. in any format (It seems to have only been released to home video in Japan, Germany, Italy and Australia). I found a decent widescreen print on YouTube, dubbed in English (it looks as though most of the actors were speaking English). I enjoyed this film quite a lot, much more than I thought I would. I love being surprised and this film fit the bill. It is a strange excursion into the bowels of evil, full of atmosphere, which can best be described as unrelenting. Also starring Valeriano Santinelli, Lote Attila, John Morrison and Arnaldo Dell'Acqua as Polgar Moricz. Not Rated.

STRANGERS IN PARADISE (1984) - Director/producer/co-screenwriter Ulli Lommel (THE BOOGEY MAN - 1980) has made some strange and awful films in his life after leaving his native Germany and moving to the States, but nothing he has done could be depicted as strange as this sci-fi/musical that can be best described as a cross between THE STEPFORD WIVES and THE ROCKY HORROR PICTURE SHOW (both 1975), only this film is so bad that I was busting a gut laughing at what was taking place on the screen. Master mesmerist Jonathan Sage (director Lommel) escapes Germany during World War II to England after Hitler (Lommel again) wants to use him to hypnotise the populace to do his bidding. While London is being bombed, Sage is cryrogenitically frozen with instructions not to be dethawed before the time is right. Cut to the town of Paradise Hills, California ca. 1984, and the parents of punk rockers, homosexuals, prostitutes, etc. try to straighten out their children using a device called the "Repentogram". The device works for about five minutes but then the kids revert back to their usual ways. Frustrated, they have one of the parents fly to London and thaw out Sage in hopes that his powers will work in place of the Repentogram. Sage, at first, is in awe at all the new inventions, including televisions, computers in every home (the only thing Lommel got right in the future, even if he was 15 years early), and all the modern conveniences. He begins working on converting a homosexual and lesbian and his powers turn them straight! Needless to say, he is a hit with the parents but there will be a steep price to pay. What make this film so funny are the frequent musical interludes that describe what Sage is doing to the mind of these youngsters. The homosexual/lesbian sequence is so funny/bad that I nearly peed my pants. He turns a Jim Morrison lookalike from a rock 'n' roller into a folk singer who then throws rock records into a bon fire in another laugh-out-loud sequence. The parents think they now have the "ultimate weapon" in the war on teenage rebellion, but they don't realize that teenage rebellion has been going on forever and that's what shaped the world. Lommel is so low-key in his role (He says, "Most things that are forbidden are the most fun" before going bowling and playing video games in another musical interlude!) that he is not so much an imposing figure as a good guy just misunderstood. Some of the musical numbers are good (especially the WWII number in London, which is intercut with German bomber planes destroying the city), but most of the numbers either fall flat or are unintentionally funny. If you are in the mood for a good laugh, I recommend this film highly. Just don't be looking for a good film. It's definitely cult material, just not good cult material. Also starring Ken Letner, Thom Jones, Geoffrey Barker, Cliff Brisbois, Ula Hedwig and a cameo by co-writer Suzanne Love (Lommel's wife at the time).  Lommel is still making films today, including CURSE OF THE ZODIAC (2006) and a bunch of other crappy SOV true life serial killer films (including ones on the B.T.K. and Green River killers) released by Lions Gate Films for home video release . A Vestron Video Release. Not Rated. The WWII number also appears as the opening theme of Domonic Paris's compilation film FILM HOUSE FEVER (1986) with early appearances by Steve Buscemi and Mark Boone Jr. as an avid film watchers who are turned into zombies in the end.

SURGIKILL (1988) - When one thinks of Andy Milligan, the thought of intentional humor doesn't automatically spring to mind. Quite the contrary, as Milligan's body of work is notorious for it's unintentional humor (not to mention the many anachronisms in his period horror films), bad acting and hectic camerawork. SURGIKILL is Milligan's last film (he died of AIDS in 1991), a kitchen-sink hospital comedy (with bits of gore) that tries to be a parody in the vein of AIRPLANE (1980), but fails on nearly every level. The acting is still uniformly awful and the sets simple (bare, white cinderblock walls are the norm here), but the camerawork is so static, it's like a filmed stage play, proving that Milligan's heart wasn't in this (he was merely a hired hand here) and was running on fumes. The story (if you can call it that) is about the employees and patients of Goode Community Hospital (the most understaffed and bare-bones hospital I have ever seen), run by Dr. Grace Goode (the single-monikered Bouvier, who is truly awful), as the hospital tries to find a way to stop from closing down and being turned into a shopping mall. This is the worst run hospital on record, as orderlies keep spilling bedpans and urine on patients and the desk nurse, Rona Ratchitt (Dan Foster-Jones in drag), cracks wise to the admitting patients, their family and the staff over the public address system. Trouble ensues when an escaped mental patient, Lizard Lips (Jim Allen), roams the halls disguised as a doctor and begins killing the patients and staff, while a new hire, 16 year-old Dr. Albert Schweitzer (Doug Eames, who sucks on a giant pacifier he wears around his neck), learns the ropes from Dr. Goode, Dr. Harvey (Michael Lunsford) and Dr. Fine (Al Silver), who are all just as inept as they come. As more patients end up dead or injured (one patient explodes when her anesthesia tank is substituted with an acetylene tank; another patient is castrated; another is pushed down a flight of stairs; and still another is hung by the neck), Dr. Goode and her staff cover-up the crimes for fear the bad publicity will shut their doors (Well, duh!), Too many patients end up dead to go unnoticed, though, as the relative of one dead patient threatens to sue and Nurse Ratchitt turns out to be Dr. Goode's only surviving male relative, who wants to kill Dr. Goode and take over the hospital. Folks, this is the longest 88 minutes I have ever experienced, as the jokes fall flatter than Olive Oyl's chest and the pacing is slower than a loved one's funeral.  This is truly painful to watch, as the script, written by Milligan, never rises above the schtick a third-rate Jewish comedian would perform in the Borscht Belt of the Catskill Mountains in the 50's & 60's (Most of the jokes here would make Henny Youngman wince. Yes, they're that bad.). Those expecting Andy Milligan's patented gorefest (including such films as TORTURE DUNGEON [1970], LEGACY OF HORROR [1979], CARNAGE [1983] and MONSTROSITY [1987]) will be doubly disappointed here. The gore is sparse (the only real instance of gore happens when the female patient explodes [offscreen] and obvious animal guts and intestines are thrown on everyone in the operating room) and the acting (including an undertaker that looks and acts like Oliver Hardy!) is even broader (and brutally terrible) than normal. I honestly can't imagine what Milligan was thinking when he was making this, as it is desperate even by his standards (Maybe he was experiencing the early effects of AIDS). Even as a little-seen relic, SURGIKILL is so unfunny that it transcends being unfunny and becomes the sort of film a Death Row prisoner would watch to make what life he has left on Earth seem a little longer than it actually is. A total abomination and not the way to end a career, even if your name is Andy Milligan. Also starring Peter Linardi, Carroll Oden, Jeremy Logan, Lynn Angus, Patrick Thomas, Michael Buckband, Robert Odell (who gets the patented Milligan "meatcleaver-to-the-head" death), Shari London, Kip Reynolds and porn star Joey Silvera. Produced and released on VHS by Media Arts Productions, LLC. The film was supposed to get a DVD release in 2011, but it looks like it never happened. Not Rated, but there's nothing here (nudity, foul language or violence) that goes beyond a PG-13 rating.

TEENALIEN (1978) - Before I proceed with the review, I first must explain why I am being kinder to this film than most no-budget junk that riddled the video store shelves in the 80's. This is one of those rare films where a bunch of teens in Utah decided to make a horror film without any knowledge of how to do so and actually achieved their dream, if their dream consisted of making a horror film that contains absolutely no blood, nudity or foul language. And then get a deal to have it released on home video! It's actually a throwback to the sci-fi/horror films of the 50's, when none of that stuff was needed to tell a story. TEENALIEN is most certainly an awful film, but it is fascinating to watch. The film opens in the late 50's with old man Dobbs (Keith Nelson, whose idea of acting is to lick his lips and continuously wipe his face with his hands) making his special brand of "squeeze" liquor while some creature with red glowing eyes lumbers outside his cabin. Dobbs hears a loud buzzing sound outside, so he grabs his squeeze and checks out the commotion, only to witness an alien spacecraft rising from behind a building known as the Old Mill. The spaceship flies directly overhead of Dobbs and emits a green ray, whose purpose seems to be to evaporate the squeeze liquor in the jar Dobbs is holding (Maybe the aliens needed a drink before their long trip). Twenty years later, teenager Carl (Michael Dunn) is looking for a house to put on a Halloween spook show, so kindly old-timer Mr. Cranston (Vern Adix), the owner of the Old Mill, offers it to Carl to use free of charge. Carl is a little reticent about accepting the offer because the Old Mill is said to be haunted (a flashback to 100 years earlier shows the red-eyed alien killing the dog of a couple of miners when it enters an open window of the Old Mill), but Mr. Cranston talks him into it. This doesn't sit too well with Carl's rival, Tony (Dan Harville), who was planning to put on a spook show of his own, but there is no way he can compete with the Old Mill. Tony gets some unexpected help from a nameless white-haired teen (Mike McClure, who is as stiff as a mahogany headboard), who offers to help Tony and his gang scare Carl and his friends out of using the Old Mill. Carl and his friends, which includes the hulking Tiny (Dale Angell), begin to get the musty Old Mill ready for the spook show and discover some creepy mannequins in a closet that are made from some unknown material, so they decide to use them as props in the show. After also discovering some strange bones (that make strange metallic sounds when dropped) and a hidden tunnel that leads to a secret laboratory, it becomes obvious to Carl that there's more going on here than meets the eye. When members of Carl's crew begin being abducted by mysterious figures wearing black hooded robes, Carl and his friends must uncover the truth before it becomes too late. Of course, the people in the hooded robes turn out to be Tony and his friends, but that strange white-haired teen turns out to be something more sinister: an alien called a Varrow, who has come to Earth on a mission to take over our planet because theirs is overpopulated (Which begs the question: Why would they wait over a hundred years to do so?). Carl discovers the truth, as the Varrow transforms itself to its normal big red bug-eyed self and chases Carl and everyone elser around the Old Mill. Can Carl and younger brother Mike (Chad Bennion) convince the police that this isn't a Halloween prank before more Varrows arrive on Earth?  Also known as THE VARROW MISSION, first (and only)-time director/producer Peter Semelka tries his damnedest to give this film a "Hey gang, let's put on a show!" atmosphere, but the amateur acting, bad cinematography (which mainly consists of medium and long shots) and out-of-place music score doom the project from the start. The screenplay, by Semelka and executive producer James Crofts (based on a story by Ed & Sherma Yeates), has some decent ideas, but the paltry budget is unable to communicate those ideas in an effective manner. Don't get me wrong, it's definitely fun watching everyone trying their hardest to communicate those ideas, but it fails at every turn, making this film akin to watching the after effects of a bad car wreck as you slowly drive by it. The majority of the film is nothing but teens mucking about the Old Mill wearing various Halloween costumes, but there are a few creepy scenes, including the arrival of a female Varrow (Judy Richards); the transformation of the male Varrow from human to alien (which is nearly ruined by Mike McClure's horrible acting ability); and the revelation that the Varrow have been living amongst us for decades (one is even a local cop), which leads to an INVASION OF THE BODY SNATCHERS (1956)-like finale. This was truly a community production (filmed in Salt Lake County, Utah), as many of the "actors" in front of the camera also worked behind them doing various jobs to keep costs down. TEENALIEN may be strictly amateur hour, but it is still an entertaining artifact from the 70's. Also starring Alex Churchich, Steve Bartlett, Ken Johnson, Roger Hamblin, Holly Harkness, Sally Jones and Dave Olson as the Varrow alien (which is your typical BEM). Originally released on VHS by Prism Entertainment and available on DVD (as THE VARROW MISSION) from JEF Films, who are not known for quality replication, not to mention legality of licensing. Rated PG.

THE THIRD EYE (1966) - "The third eye, it always stares in the same direction."  Who knew that Joe D'Amato's seminal gore film BEYOND THE DARKNESS (a.k.a. BURIED ALIVE - 1979) was actually a remake?!? One look at this fairly unknown black and white Italian film of the perverse will show you where D'Amato got his impetus to make his gore epic. While not nearly as gory as D'Amato's flick, this film is sleazy to the extreme (it may be the sleaziest '60s film I have ever seen and I've seen plenty!), with bursts of graphic violence that will surprise viewers. It is also adult in its depictions of sex, love and death, so much so, that it should open the eyes of genre enthusiasts wider than they thought their eyes could open. Yes, it is that good.
     The film opens with young Count Mino Alberti (Franco Nero; KEOMA - 1976; here billed as "Frank Nero") waiting impatiently for the love of his life, Laura (Erika Blanc; THE DEVIL'S NIGHTMARE - 1971; here billed as "Diana Sullivan"), to pick flowers for Mino's overbearing and domineering mother (Olga Solbelli; MILL OF THE STONE WOMEN - 1960; billed here as "Olga Sunbeauty", a literal translation of her Italian name), who hates Laura with every ounce of her rather large body. Laura hands the flowers over to the maid, Marta (Gioia Pascal), who destroys them when Laura leaves the room, because she has had the hots for Mino since she was a child. Mother Alberti keeps close tabs on her son; she even has a secret peephole she uses to spy on her son in his bedroom! Laura is about to leave for a few days to visit her sister in Switzerland (Mother Alberti makes a snotty remark to Laura, basically calling her a liar, comparing her trip to a servant asking for a few days off to visit a sick relative, telling Laura it is just an excuse for lazy workers to get a few days off) and Mino wants to have sex with her before she leaves, but Laura is not in the mood and finds Mino's unrelenting advances quite troublesome (telling him, "I feel uncomfortable living with you in this house."). Marta mentions to Mother Alberti that when Laura returns from this trip, she will marry Mino and she will no longer be living with her son because Laura won't let him, so Mother Alberti makes a comment, saying wouldn't it be nice if she never returned? Marta knows exactly what she means and we then see Marta cutting the brake line on Laura's car!
     We then discover that Mino is a taxidermist (just as in D'Amato's film), his specialty being birds (There is a scene of Mino preparing a dead bird for taxidermy with him cutting into its body with a scalpel and then removing its internal organs with his hands. It's as graphic as any gore scene I have witnessed, even though it is in black and white!). While Mino is working in his laboratory, Marta tells Laura that Mino went away and will not be able to see her off, so Laura decides to leave early, saying goodbye to Mother Alberti, getting in her car and driving off, down the steep mountain road, full of dangerous sharp curves. When Mino discovers Laura left early (look at the sly grin on Marta's face when she tells him), he jumps in his car and tries to catch up with her (Even though we know what is going to happen, this sequence is white knuckle suspense at its finest). Mino catches up with Laura and starts beeping his horn, but when Laura tries to stop her car, she discovers she has no brakes and Mino watches helplessly as Laura's car rolls down a steep embankment to the ocean below. Mino runs down the embankment and discovers Laura's dead body hanging out of her wrecked car, her head under the water (Mino cries out, "No! No! No! Noooo!").
     At the same time this is taking place, Marta and Mother Alberti get into a heated argument and Mother Alberti orders Marta to pack up her things and leave the house immediately, she is no longer in her employ. While Marta begs to keep her job, she accidentally (?) pushes the frail Mother Alberti down a flight of stairs, which results in a deep cut on the side of Mother Alberti's face (very graphic). Since she is someone to take advantage of a situation, Marta strangles Mother Alberti with her bare hands.
     When a despondent Mino returns home, he discovers that his day is about to get much worse. He opens the front door to discover Marta crying uncontrollably (crocodile tears), while the police inform him that his mother has died in a "tragic accident" (A doctor tells Marta that she is to stick close by Mino because he is going to need her more than ever. Marta then stops crying and give a shit-eating grin that will send shivers down your spine!). It is at this time Mino's mind snaps, telling Marta that his laboratory is to remain locked and never opened again ("I don't want to see these birds anymore! Nobody may go inside there! Nobody!" Pay attention to the stuffed owl in Mino's laboratory. It explains the passage of time expertly and eerily.). It is obvious (after a short while) why Mino wants no one in his laboratory. What is shown in D'Amato's film is only hinted at here. Mino then goes into his bedroom and collapses on his bed, as a finely edited sequence shows us what is going through Mino's mind, making it clear that his mind has snapped into madness.
     The next time we have seen Mino, a year has passed and he's sitting in a nightclub watching a female trumpet player (!) and a band playing a tune. The hostess announces that exotic dancer Marie Margot (Marina Morgan; THE SHERIFF OF ROCK SPRINGS - 1971) is about to perform and Mino watches rapt as she does an erotic striptease (while we see no nudity, it's still very daring for its time). We then see that Mino has brought her home with him. He takes her into his "special" bedroom and tells her to take off her clothes. She takes them off (at least down to her bra and panties) and notices a bouquet of dead flowers and some dead birds in the room, but thinks nothing of it. She then gets down to business with a fully dressed Mino on a bed, but when she turns her head, she lets out an ear-piercing scream (for some reason, this part of the sequence changes from Italian to German language, but for less than a minute). We then see Mino choking the life out of Marie with his bare hands, while the taxidermied body of Laura lies on a bed next to them. Marta hears the screams and runs into the room, finding Marie's dead body and Laura's corpse. Knowing full well that she has Mino just where she wants him, she half-heartedly tells Mino that they should contact the police, but when a crying Mino begs her to help him, she says they will have to re-open his laboratory and fully dispose of Marie's body in his vat of hydrochloric acid (off-screen, unlike D'Amato's film).
     We then see that Mino is interested in taxidermy again and, in a very telling scene, we see him torturing a live parrot with a wooden rod. The next time we see the parrot, it is dead and stuffed, only this time Mino treats it like a friend, petting its feathers like it was a dog (showing us the stark difference about his feelings for the living and the dead). Taking Marta's advice, Mino goes out to break up the monotony of his life, picking up a prostitute named Loredana (Gara Granda; BARBARELLA - 1968), giving her an enormous amount of money and bringing her home to his special bedroom. Just like Marie, Mino strangles her in the bed. He tells Marta, "I have killed again. It's as though suddenly I had a third eye. The third eye, it always stares in the same direction." Marta knows she now has Mino over a barrel, telling him if he wants her help, "You listen to me now. Since I was brought into this world, I only took orders. I worked like a slave. I also grew up in this house and I saw wealth all around me, out of my reach. I was no more than an employee to all of you. But that's over now. Now...you must come to grips with life on your own. Whatever I want, that's what you said, no? Say it again [he does]. I will stay, Mino...on one condition. I want to be your wife. You are sick, Mino, and you know it. I also know there is no cure. It would be deception not to realize that. You will always need new sacrifices. Only a woman who shares everything with you can understand you and will be able to help you. I will be an understanding wife to you, for better or worse. What do you say?" Mino, of course agrees to her demands, but neither of them are prepared for what happens next.
     That would be Laura's sister Diana (Erika Blanc again), who is the spitting image of Laura. She has come to Villa Alberti to talk to Mino and hopefully find the body of her missing sister. When Marta sets sights on her as she steps out of her car, she is horrified, not because Diana looks exactly like Laura, but knowing that her impending marriage to Mino is now over. She tries to get Diana to leave by telling her that Mino is on a trip and won't be back for quite some time, but Mino, who has just returned from hunting (for more birds to taxidermy), walks out of the woods, sets sight on Diana and thinks Laura has returned to him. Mino informs Marta that they can no longer get married because he is about to marry Laura, so there is no longer any room in his life for her. Marta reminds him that Laura is dead and so is his mother, but Mino, who is quite mad, tells Marta, "Get out of my house! Go away! Get out of here, immediately! Liar! Liar!...Liar! Liar!" As you would expect, Marta is having none of this, so she grabs a butcher knife out of the kitchen drawer and goes into Diana's bedroom to kill her. Marta accidentally knocks something over on Diana's night table, waking her up and all Marta can do is slash one of Diana's palms before she runs away, Marta in close pursuit. Diana hides in Mino's special bedroom and discovers the stuffed body of her sister (as well as some kind of insect that tries to bite her hand, in a scene that will have you rewinding it several times). Just as Marta is about to kill Diana, Mino grabs the knife out of her hands and viciously stabs Marta repeatedly in the stomach (It's about as strong a scene you will witness in any 1960's production). Knowing that Diana has seen her sister's body (or perhaps he doesn't know), he places her unconscious body in his car and drives off. When she wakes up and hears Mino call her Laura, telling her he is taking her to a special place to get married, Diana knows she must escape, but Mino keeps her at bay with a pistol he keeps in his jacket pocket. Mino stops at a gas station when he notices the tank is almost empty and Diana quietly throws Mino registration papers out the car window as they leave. An attendant at the station finds the papers and calls the police (This is Italy and you should know you should never be without your registration papers). In the film's most intense scene, the police phone Mino's house and we discover that Marta is not quite dead, but the ringing telephone is on the other side of the room and a seriously wounded Marta must crawl to it. When the phone stops ringing, it looks like Marta has missed the call, but the policeman phones again (just in case he called the wrong number the first time) and Marta makes it to the phone. The police arrive at the house and Marta tells them everything (blaming Mino for everything, telling them, "Find him. Find the murderer!") just before she dies.
     The police put an all points bulletin (APB) on Mino's car and we then see that Mino has taken Diana to the beach by the ocean and he's quite crazy, telling Diana, "We will spend the night together, the longest night we've ever known. Just us alone. You and me.  Brighten up, brighten up, little candle. Life is no more than fleeting shadows. A wonderful fairytale designed for idiots. Everything is noise and fireworks with no meaning. I can already smell the scent of the sea. But there is nothing I prefer to the scent of you, Laura!" Diana tells him Laura is dead, but Mino puts his hands over his ears, because he doesn't want to hear it. Diana tries to run away, but Mino tackles her in the sand and rips the clothes off her body. A squad of police with flashlights arrive (a well composed sequence) and stops Mino from raping Diana, Mino telling the police that Diana kidnapped him after killing his maid, not knowing that Marta already spilled the beans on him. The head detective plays along and puts Mino in the back of his car, not even bothering to handcuff him, telling an officer it will not be necessary, it will only take a few minutes to clear this up. As they drive away, Mino thinks he got away with it all, not knowing that he is about to have a rude wakeup call when he arrives at the station. The film ends on this note.
     This is a terrific thriller, quite unlike anything that had come out of Italy, or anywhere for that matter, in the '60s.  Very adult in its approach and full of unflinching brutality, this may be my favorite Franco Nero performance of his long and storied career (Nero says that this was the film that got him noticed as a serious actor). He's absolutely amazing as a man driven to insanity by an overbearing mother and a skewed sense of love because of it, giving him no moral center at all. As a matter of fact everyone here is terrific. There's not a false note in any of the performances. I particularly liked the way Erika Blanc gave her two characters different personalities. Laura is serious and abrupt while Diana is bubbly and trusting. She has always impressed me, no matter what role she plays. I was also surprised to discover that actress Gioia Pascal never appeared in anything else after starring in this. She is excellent as the conniving Marta and I would be very interested to learn why she gave up acting. Director Mino Guerrini (DATE FOR A MURDER - 1967; THE MINES OF KILIMANJARO - 1986), who takes the Anglicized name "James Warren" here and co-wrote the screenplay with "Dean Craig" (actually Piero Regnoli, who would write the screenplays to the gore classics CITY OF THE WALKING DEAD - 1980 and BURIAL GROUND - 1980), keeps things moving at a brisk pace and gives us plenty of well-composed camera shots and some unusual photography (black & white cinematography by Alessandro D'Eva; UNCLE WAS A VAMPIRE - 1959; DEATH WALKS ON HIGH HEELS - 1971; who uses the pseudonym "Sandy Eaves" here), especially showing us Mino going mad by focusing on his eyes rolling into the back of his head as his face hits the camera lens, making this film a feast for the eyes as well as the brain. As much as I'm a fan of Joe D'Amato's film, I have to admit that I like this one better, because instead of showing us unrated gore, as D'Amato's film does, it deals with the violence in more literal terms, using dialogue and some finely-tuned camera shots (such as the stuffed owl showing us the progress of time, simply by putting cobwebs on it). I think I have discovered my new favorite film and believe me when I say that doesn't come along too often. If Franco Mannino's ("Frank Mason" in the credits) music score sounds familiar (It is incorrectly listed as belonging to Francesco De Masi on IMDb) it's because you already heard it before, as the soundtrack to Riccardo Freda's THE GHOST (1963). Ruggero Deodato, the director of CANNIBAL HOLOCAUST (1980) was Assistant Director here, using the name "Roger Drake".
     Shot as IL TERZO OCCHIO (a literal translation of the review title), this film never saw the light of day on home video in any physical form in the United States. I know I am always praising Amazon Prime for offering rare films streaming for free to Prime members and I'm about to do it again, because they offer a fairly clean anamorphic widescreen print in its original Italian (except for the small German language section) with non-removable English subtitles. I could go on and on praising this film and telling you how foolish it is not to be a Prime member, but I am going to stop right here and let you discover the film on your own. Also featuring Richard Hillock as the doctor who talks to Marta and Luciano Foti (AUTOPSY - 1973) as the policeman who phones Mino's house. Not Rated.

THIRSTY FOR LOVE, SEX AND MURDER (1972) - This is a strange one: A barely hour-long, scene-for-scene Turkish rip-off of director Sergio Martino's THE STRANGE VICE OF MRS. WARDH (1971), but with a totally different and bizarre ending that must be seen to be believed. And the really strange thing is that it actually works! While you don't have to watch Martino's film to enjoy this cheapie, it helps if you do, if only to spot the scenes that were copied verbatim from Martino's film. As with all Turkish genre fare, it also helps if you toss aside all logic and just go along for the ride. You should also imbibe in a controlled substance or plenty of alcohol (or both), because this film should not be watched sober.
     A man wearing dark sunglasses and a black hat watches a funeral at a cemetery in his car in the pouring rain. He then picks up a woman on the side of the road, who asks him for a ride to town. She notices a short time later that he is not heading towards town, foolishly thinking that he is taking a shortcut. He stops his car by some barren woods, puts on some black gloves and tries to assault the women, but she gets out of the car and runs into the forest (Pay close attention to the ground. In one scene there is heavy snow on the ground and the next scene shows some nice green grass!). The man runs after her and she thinks she has gotten away, hiding behind a tree. She then walks into an open field and, suddenly, the man jumps at her, ripping off her coat (Where in the hell did he come from? It's an open field for Christ's sake, don't you think she would have seen him coming? Remember what I said about tossing aside all logic? Maybe I should practice what I preach!). The woman breaks free and runs into the barren forest once again (The forest is so barren, we can see a crew member's hand holding a branch so the camera can get a shot of the killer's POV as he approaches the woman. I can't make this shit up!). The woman cowers as the killer comes closer to her because she trapped with nowhere to run. She begs the man not to hurt her because she's engaged (!), saying, "I am only 17, that would ruin me. Show some mercy, please!" (If she's 17, I'm a freakin' infant!). The man ogles her body, spending way too much time looking at her legs and she begs for mercy one final time, then unbuttoning her blouse and taking off her skirt, standing in front of the man in her white bra and panties, the man not uttering a single word (How in the hell did she know he wanted sex? Oh, nevermind!).  We then see the man climbing on top of the woman's topless body as she lies on the ground, a straight razor in his hand. He then slashes her body repeatedly as a plane flies overhead.
     We then watch the plane land at the airport and one of the passengers is Mine (Meral Zeren), who is greeted by her diplomat husband, Metin (Nihat Zeyalan), who says that the trip to Europe must have been good for her nerves because she looks good. Mine tells him it would have been better if he were there with her, but he tells her that his government position hardly leaves him time to even think about her (Ah, husbands and wives!). We slowly begin to realize that Mine went to Europe to get away from her violent illicit lover Tarik (Yildirim Gencer; SPY SMASHER - 1968), who would slap her around when they made love. As Metin and Mine are leaving the airport, their car is stopped by the police, who ask to see their papers, telling them that a woman had been raped and murdered near the airport and before she died, the woman told the police that her attacker had a huge scar on his right cheek. Mine then has a flashback where she is sexually assaulted by Tarik in the rain and she fights back, cutting his right cheek with a broken bottle. Could Tarik be the killer or is that too easy? In Turkey, nothing is too easy.
     Mine and Metin arrive home, Metin taking a shower and Mine getting ready for bed, when there's a knock on the door. A deliveryman hands her a bouquet of flowers and the card reads, "I am so glad you came home. I can't wait to hold you in my arms." If any of this sounds like déjà vu, don't fret, as you are about to experience a whole lot more, only it's not going to be like any déjà vu you ever experienced before. It's akin to remembering a delicious meal at an expensive restaurant, only this time you'll be eating a Big Mac with a side of fries to go. That's the best way to describe this film. It may be copying Sergio Martino's excellent giallo film, only this time it is being done with a crazy Turkish slant. In other words, made with a budget that couldn't afford that expensive dinner at a fancy restaurant, barely able to pay for that burger and fries.
